meta.title: Information & Updates - Rosemount-Apple Valley-Eagan ISD 196

body.class: fsLiveMode fsHasHeader fsHasMenu fsHasFooter fsHasOneColumnLayout fsSection331 fsHasTheme2

li.a: Bilingual and Multilingual Seals and Certificates

div.br:
We are nationally recognized for providing boundless opportunities in which students can learn and grow. Our work is grounded in our "Triple-A" philosophy of academics, arts and athletics.
Enroll today!

img.alt: A young elementary students sits at a table and smiles.
Three female students in hijabs and a District 196 staff member smile for a photo in a library.

li.a: Bilingual and Multilingual Seals and Certificates

img.alt: Lisa Turgeon explains a Native American artifact to a child.
Superintendent Mary Kreger works with a teacher and student.

p.span: This information is intended to update the District 196 community on our response plan to the outbreak of the novel coronavirus (COVID-19). The situation is rapidly-evolving and updates change daily as new information becomes available.

div.h2: All District 196 schools are closed through the end of the 2019-20 school year, in response to an executive order by Gov. Tim Walz.
div.p: All activities and events at district sites are canceled. Teachers and administrators implemented distance learning with students on Monday, March 30.

A licensed school nurse isavailable for phone calls, from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m., at two child care locations. For the Cedar Park Elementary location, call 952-431-8361. For the Oak Ridge Elementary location, call 651-683-8593.
Asistencia en español. | Caawinta Afka ee Af-soomaaliga.

p.span: There is currently no vaccine to prevent coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The best way to prevent illness is to avoid being exposed to this virus. The virus is thought to spread from person-to-person. Maintain a distance of at least 6 feet if you need to be out in public but the best way prevent is to #StayHomeMN

div.h2: Wash your hands frequently with soap and water.
div.p: Washing hands for at least 20 seconds especially after you have been in a public place, or after blowing your nose, coughing, or sneezing. If soap and water are not readily available, use a hand sanitizer that contains at least 60% alcohol. Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.

div.h2: Cover your nose and mouth when coughing or sneezing.
div.p: Cover your mouth and nose with a tissue when you cough or sneeze or use the inside of your elbow. Throw used tissues in the trash.

p.span: Stay home if you are sick. Keep kids home if they or someone you're in contact with is sick.

div.p: Put distance, at least 6 feet, between yourself and other people. Putting distance between yourself and other people if COVID-19 is spreading in your community. This is especially important for people who are at higher risk of getting sick.

Clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces daily including tables, doorknobs, light switches, countertops, handles, desks, phones, keyboards, toilets, faucets and sinks. Use detergent or soap and water prior to disinfection.

p.small: * Imagery is produced by the Centers for Disease Control & Prevention, for full details go to https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleTwoThirds fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear
fsElement fsPostElement fsGrid fsThumbnailRectangle fsThumbnailLarge fsItemCount_6

div.a: Distance learning extended through the end of the school year
District to resume use of Zoom videoconferencing platform

div.title: A bag of lunch that includes a sandwich and apple.

img.alt: A bag of lunch that includes a sandwich and apple.

div.a: Free grab-and-go meal distribution resumes March 30

p.span: The District 196 distance learning plan is unique to support the learning of students at all grade levels.

div.p: District 196 is implementing distance learning in compliance with an executive order from Governor Walz. The distance learning plan supports the learning of students at all grade levels in District 196 with a goal to provide meaningful learning for students and maintain personalized connections in the event that students are unable to be in the school building(s) due to an emergency situation (e.g. epidemic or other emergency).

The distance learning plan includes grades K-3 learning opportunities, both online and offline, and grades 4-12 learning opportunities that incorporate a larger use of our digital platforms. We are fortunate that for grades 4-12, we have a robust one-to-one technology learning environment that includes Schoology, our learning management system.

We recognize that learning at home and/or online provides a different educational experience than the traditional learning environment we are accustomed to within schools. We are dedicated to facilitating meaningful learning as effectively as possible in these circumstances, given the tools available. We also recognize our staff, students, and families may be facing unprecedented challenges during an emergency closure and we all need to be patient, supportive, and understanding. Flexibility and communication is key as we navigate emergency school closure and distance learning.
Asistencia en español. | Caawinta Afka ee Af-soomaaliga.

img.alt: young elementary student girl on laptop

div.p: The goal is for K-5 students to be engaged in learning for a total of 2.5 hours throughout each day as the students navigate and complete learning activities and related tasks as part of the learning community.

img.alt: Boy working on a computer in a library

div.p: The goal is for secondary students to be engaged in learning, as a general guideline, for no more than 40 minutes per class per day for those classes that met on a daily basis. This includes time for completing assignments/tasks and any direct instruction.

p.a: For all other programming, visit our District Learning page.

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleTwoThirds fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear
fsElement fsPostElement fsList fsThumbnailOriginal fsThumbnailSmall fsItemCount_10

div.a: Dakota County COVID-19 Resources (opens in new window/tab)
Helping children cope with changes resulting from COVID-19 (opens in new window/tab)
Where can students get free meals?
How is attendance taken during distance learning?
What is the Families First Coronavirus Response Act?
What do I do if I have a Charter/Spectrum internet connectivity issue?
What do I do if I don't have reliable internet access?
What should I do if I have traveled to an area highly affected by COVID-19?
What should I do if someone in my household is sick?

div.class: fsDiv fsStyleTwoThirds fsStyleColumn fsStyleColumn-2 fsStyleColumn-last fsStyleAutoclear

div.p: In District 196, we believe learning is maximized in a safe, respectful and inclusive environment. As a learning community, we must continue to be united and support one another as the coronavirus (COVID-19) becomes more widespread. In our schools, we will continue to demonstrate compassion and care with all students and staff.

It is important to avoid prejudice to students, staff and community members during this time who may be ill or assuming that someone may have COVID-19. Preventing the spread of misinformation will help us continue providing safe and healthy learning environment for all of our students.
